review_body: Honolulu is dominated by the Waikiki high-rise hotels. If that doesn't appeal to you, the Manoa Valley Inn offers a pleasant and affordable alternative. It's an historic property that's an island of green in an otherwise unremarkable area two blocks from the University of Hawaii. Breakfast was excellent, and was served on a lovely terrace that's nearly overgrown with orchards and other plants. There's a garden area and pool in the back as well, though they're not well cared for. As B&B's go, Manova Valley has some shortcomings. Parking is very tight, so don't arrive in a Hummer and hog a space and a half. The room we had was nice enough and big enough for two, and it had a good bed. But the furnishings were well-worn and the shower/bath was substandard. The on-site management owns friendly dogs and they (the dogs) show up from time to time, which I personally didn't care for. The Inn is walking distance to the University but not much else, so finding good restaurants nearby where you can also park is a real challenge (and a common problem throughout Honolulu). I'm glad we chose this over the Waikiki skyscrapers, but Manoa Valley could use some attention to make it a first-rate B&B experience.

I gave this bnb a full 5 because it achieves what it sets out to do. A sanctuary away from the brutal( not my words, a locals) high rises of Waikiki. The Inn is not a brand new glossy hotel of which you are in 1 room of hundreds but it does have a comfy bed,a/c and a wonderful substantial breakfast. it is a family home that is welcoming and a delight to return home to at the end of the day. I had a room at the top, my bathroom had a slanted roof so if you are tall maybe mention this to get an appropriate space for you. Given the time of year I visited I didn't even need the a/c as I was able to open the windows in my room for the breeze off the mountains. The staff are very friendly, polite and accommodating. Hopefully I will return one day!

The staff did not speak English very well. There were dogs in the public spaces.There was a definite smell of dog urine in the porch area. The area did not look like pictures. We left but were given a refund. My only reason for giving it a poor not terrible rating

So glad I found this gem! The rooms are spacious and lovely (a few too many knick knacks, but no big deal). The property is beautifully maintained which makes it feel like you’re walking into a botanical garden, right in the middle of the city. The staff was friendly and helpful - they even packed me coffee and food to go on the morning I had to leave before 7:00. The food itself is delicious and plentiful: eggs and pancakes made to order, meat, potatoes, cooked vegetables, rice, bread, fresh fruit and juice, and coffee. A perfect alternative to the crowded, touristy beach scene.

The Manoa Valley is a a great place to stay in Honolulu. It is very near the University of Hawaii, not far from Waikiki and close to restaurants. The gardens and pool are beautiful and a nice peaceful place in the midst of a busy city. The innkeepers were very friendly and helpful and the breakfast was excellent. Our room was comfortable and air conditioned, which helped in the hot summer weather. We would definitely stay here again if we visit Honolulu in the future.

I am genuinely confused with the good reviews this place has. The pictures are very deceiving, they must be using filters for these pics because this place is run down and dirty, smells terrible, no A/C, No privacy, the window treatments were very thin and I could see the neighbor in his garage while I used the bathroom. I dint think the sheets are cleaned and if they are they dont get cleaned properly I was very very ichy and there were deffinatly bugs of all kinds here. Could not sleep here even for one night but had to pay for ALL THREE NIGHTS NO REFUNDS. The parking is a joke. It's very musty and hard to breathe in this place.The owners live in this house and I could hear them all day/night talking outside inside where ever. Just dont go. Please.

Beautiful historic building with wonderful innkeepers. The breakfast was sumptuous and the setting beautiful.The parking became more challenging as more guests arrived. Very nice to have AC in a historical inn!

Our family of ten stayed here to get away from the hustle and bustle but still experience Honolulu. Easy airport access, next to University of Hawaii and shops/restaurants, lovely nearby Tantalus and Diamond Head, and we could even enjoy Waikiki Friday night fireworks from our room windows! The family caretakers of the inn are very kind, considerate and welcoming, and the inn is so beautiful-especially the garden.

I got my dates wrong and needed a place to stay for a night. This came up so i booked it. Its off the beaten track in a quiet area. Parking can be tight but was ok. We were met by a huge dog. Very friendly. Check in easy. We got a room on 3rd floor which could be a problem if you dont like stairs as there is no lift. Room was nice but you can hear your neighbours. The bathroom is an add on with a sloping ceiling so unless you are 3 feet tall you cannot stand up in the shower. Nice bed and very comfortable room. Breakfsst was invluded and very good. Overall a very nice place with nice folk running it.

LOVE LOVE LOVE this place! Love the garden, the porch, the pool and breakfast. It's very intimate bed and breakfast and it's very clean. However, here are the things to note:* They need a better way for parking* All you will get is a liquid soap in a bottle that smells great! - So bring your own soap/shampoos/conditioner/lotion.* It's a humid state and they keep the room windows open, so the sheets has musty smell. (When your dish sponge is old smell).* There is a massage service for $68. We have not tried it yet, but we will when we're back.

We are two couples who traveled to Hawaii for the first time, attending the Marathon and the Eagles concert (among other things). Our plane arrived late at night and had no problem having our room ready by 11PM. The view, in the morning, was quite nice, overlooking busy Waikiki and the property garden (we stayed on the 3rd floor, Davie room). Breakfast was ready by 7h30 and was very good. Fruit selection varied depending of the day and most jams were of the organic kind. Eggs and waffle were done as we like it and the croissant really good.This is an old style, 100+ year old mansion, that has kept it's charm and while many people inhabit the property, they were very accommodating. Please note that there is no elevator (no problem for us). The garden is a nice retreat if you can find the time to enjoy and the cats and dogs were very well behaved and accustomed to visitor. The few staff we encountered were very good for our special request.While there is not that many places around for diner (this is a residential area), you're never more that 5-10 minutes by car from Waikiki or any other local eatery. The local bus is right around the corner.If you like old style mansion, antics, history and quietness, this is a great place to spend a few nights. We recommend MVI to our friends. Mahalo !

amazingly clean for such an old historic home with people coming and going daily. We loved being out of Waikiki. The staff are wonderful. Loved the pets (we did not notice a smell as someone else commented). We are 'animal' people and even a few goats and chickens would have been fine with us! The creaky floors, antique decor and gardens are of a time gone by. Just a nice change from everywhere else. Gives you a feeling of what a stately old house would have been like to live in a hundred years ago (without the plumbing). The owners and staff extend themselves and this old home is a labor of love. This is not a modern hotel.. No resort and parking fees. Breakfast included, and personal attention. If you are simply burned out on the high pace of Waikiki and just want some R&R with historic charm, this is a lovely place to spend some time.

This Bed and Breakfast is one of the few remaining estate houses in the area. It sits on a hill near the University of Hawaii campus. The guest rooms are named after individuals who were important in the history of the house. We stayed in the Davis Room on the third floor with a view of the Waikiki Beach Hotels and Diamondhead. Not all rooms have this view. This is a three story house with no elevators. The Breakfast offered fruits, coffee, and breads. Eggs and pancakes are made to order.The grounds are lush with vegetation and a swimming pool is available but is somewhat overwhelmed by the lush vegetation. Parking is available but somewhat limited.The room was comfortable and clean and we slept well.Upon checkout we accidentally left a credit card in the room. They called us by phone to tell us they found it and offered air express it to our home. It arrived with a nice note and a package of Hawaiian Kakimochi cookies at no charge to us.If you enjoy a quiet bed and breakfast with an opportunity to interact with other guests then you will enjoy your stay.

A wonderful bed and breakfast in a mansion filled with antiques in the city but away from the hustle and bustle of Honolulu. We only started overnight but loved it. Friendly staff, beautiful property with a small swimming pool and nice breakfast with organic food. Wonderful coffee. The bed and breakfast is run by a Japanese family who also does acupuncture. I arrived for the beginning of my vacation with a sciatica attack and had them give me a treatment before I left. I felt so much better with just one treatment and wishing a couple of days I was back to normal. I must thank them for saving my snorkeling and horseback riding vacation!!

We enjoyed our stay at this b&b. The beds are comfy, the garden is beautiful (even though we weren't able to enjoy it much due to the tropical storm) and the breakfast was excellent. You can order any egg or pancake for breakfast, eat delicious melon or crispy bacon. Good balance of price and was quality! Bonus is the many dogs, definitely the very big fluffy one, he was adorable.

We stayed with a wonderful family (ohana). Daily delicious breakfast and then off to see the beautiful local sights. Manoa Valley Inn is close to University Of Hawaii so there are lots of local "inexpensive" restaurants to frequent. Our last day we went to Waikiki Beach and there was so much traffic and high prices that it made us appreciate our local. We would pick this bnb again upon returning to visit....Aloha..

This truly was a lovely B&B. The building, the garden and pool were unique and very pleasant. We were greeted warmly by the caretakers and they fulfilled all our needs. The breakfast was delicious and filling. The fresh fruit was exceptional.We were on the second floor in a comfortable room. The air temperature and the bed were just right. My only critique would be the large window that let in lots of light in the morning. Some sort of room darkening shade would be nice (I like to sleep in).My wife and I spent our last morning reading by and swimming in the pool. The energy was positive and very relaxing.I highly recommend this property!

We arrived late at night, well after normal check-in time, but our hosts were up to greet us warmly. We were immediately taken in by the old-style architecture, a rarity in Hawaii where wooden buildings rarely last long. The home is over a hundred years old, and has been owned by some of the more famous historical figures of Hawaiian history, which added to the ambiance.We were taken to our room on the third floor, and reveled in the view of the Waikiki Beach lights, and in the morning we saw Diamond Head Crater and the vast Pacific stretching out behind it. The air conditioning made for a pleasant sleep, as did the comfortable bed. When we woke, we had tea on the back yard deck, and had a tour of the garden as breakfast was being prepared. The garden is well maintained and full of tropical plants and fruit trees—a virtual private jungle. I was even greeted by a gecko, the first I’d ever experienced that wasn’t trying to sell car insurance.Breakfast included fresh pineapple (the best I’ve ever tasted), several buffet items (bacon!!), and made-to-order eggs and pancakes. The staff were very attentive to my need to be gluten-free, and stopped using soy sauce on almost everything for the entire week, being sure to point out which items that included it—which were few. Not once did I get a Celiac reaction, although I was careful not to order eggs after pancakes had been cooked, as they only have a small griddle for that purpose.The bathroom is sufficient, and the shower adequate. They’ve done wonders with the plumbing considering the age of the house, and I never felt wanting, but if you like your bathrooms luxurious, you may be disappointed. We certainly were not.Later in the week we cooled down in the garden pool, which is well-shaded by trees, and is deep enough for short laps if that’s your thing.The parking was free, although a little tight at times depending on the number of guests. The neighborhood was quiet and pleasant, away from the noise of the touristy places, but not so far as to be inconvenient. In fact, most places in and around Honolulu were little more than fifteen minutes away, and that’s taking into consideration the gridlock on the H1. There’s even parking on the street outside if you need it.Our room was quiet as well, and we rarely heard other guests, even when the place was full. All the guest rooms are on the second or third floor, and there are no elevators, so if you have trouble with stairs you might want to look for something else. But then you’d be missing out on the terrific art work that adorns the walls, including both paintings and sculptures, as well as the antique furniture. Most importantly, you’d be missing out on the terrific staff that made us feel like family.We were very sad to leave at the end of the week, but we will surely be back.

I stayed for 7 nights. The room was large and even tho' Victorian is not my style, I thought it was really cool. The breakfasts had enough variety and pancakes and eggs were made to order.I enjoyed the hosts and their extended family and I liked that I could come and go as I pleased.My only complaint is that I am a very light sleeper and the movement of the famiy below my bedroom did wake me up most nights. But that's me "Princess and the Pea".I would recommend this historic B & B.

My husband & I have stayed here for our Anniversary or a "Staycation" for the past 3 years. Why? We like it's historic history and many unique rooms. It is private and you can come and go as you please. The full breakfast includes freshly ordered pancakes & eggs made for you on the lanai. The gardens are well maintained and full of flowers to take photos of too! We have met other guests on the lanai & shared tips on our favorite spots to visit.A warm cozy atmosphere prevails. Helpful to note: In Hawaii as a registered bed & breakfast, the families that live here have their extended family to attend to as well as guests. Grandma may be on the lanai,kids coming home from school,dogs roam the yard & lobby,etc... Extend them Aloha!

If this is your first time in Honolulu then don’t stay here. You want the tourist trap of Waikiki, glamorous, impersonal chain hotels, chain restaurants around the corner, crowds, shops and all that goes with a glitzy tourist city.If you’re over that, then this might be the place you’d love. It’s a bit out of Waikiki, but there’s buses or if you have a car it’s only 10 mins to where it’s all happening.Moana Valley inn is an old historic house, family run. Two families live on site along with numerous dogs and cats. We didn’t see the cats except for sitting by the window, however, my cat allergies did kick in.It’s a bit odd for us westerners, lots of family, but it’s a b& b, families live on site.They share our breakfast etc etc.We arrived on an overnight flight from Sydney at 6 am, we were warmly welcomed by Mark, one of the owners. The families were still waking up but we were taken to the breakfast area, boosted with amazingly good coffee ( I’m not usually a fan on American coffee), offered breakfast ( which was great), then shown to our room which was ready.There was none of the “ your room is not ready, leave your bags and go amuse yourselves). I’m not saying this mightn’t happen in busy time but it didn’t happen to us.The breakfast after this was a bit hit and miss. Nothing you could complain about but just different.The house is 100 years old so don’t expect perfect soundproofing,you will hear the people above and below you, and then there’s the the odd quirky bits of an old house.It’s beautifully decorated in period style. The gardens are tropical and lovely. The pool cute but a bit cold for me still in April. The inn is really close to The University if that the reason you’re in town. There’s a great Japanese restaurant an easy walk away.We had the Baldwin Room,on the first floor, and there were no complaints. Huge, soft bed. Clean bathroom . There’s a lovely sitting room down the hall where you can sit, read, indulge in a glass of wine or eat a take out meal and look at the high rises of Waikiki. Our room wasn’t cleaned or made up once in our 3 night stay, and while the staff were apologetic it was a bit odd. We did ask on the second day, but I guess they forgot.All in all, it’s a lovely venue. Not a 5 star multi national of Waikiki but great in its own way. Could be a bit more polished and “ user friendly” but we mostly enjoyed our stay.

Thoroughly enjoyed our 3 nights at the inn, lovely antique furnishings with friendly hosts and pets. Breakfast quite good but would serve starting at 7 to allow guests to get out and enjoy sites. In a residential area so nearby dining limited to walk to. Onsite parking seemed adequate with no extra fee. Did not use the pool but there if you want to.

I was very shocked by the smell that hit me when I first entered the Inn. On further inspection, I found out that the owners had multiple cats (8) and dogs (4) in the premises. The smell carries through to the rooms not just the reception/first floor. The smell in the room was so strong that it seeped into a loaf of bread that I had purchased just a day before and made it inedible. The cats do not come out, but the dogs come out occasionally to common areas. The breakfast provided is fairly good. The room was otherwise clean and well maintained. It is also closely located to the main attractions but far enough to offer you a peaceful time for strolls and walks. The building itself is of course of historic importance and there are quite beautiful furnishings that could be maintained better. Finally, the pool is not large enough for a swim. You cannot even sit overseeing the pool as the area is quite dirty and pillows are not refreshed frequently. In general, I got the feeling that the employees are more interested in running the acupuncture centre than the bed and breakfast.

-Tripping hazard in 3rd floor room, the Dillingham, into and out of shower.-Dogs too close to guests and food service. -No common area for guests.-Older house did have some charm, but more work needed.

Intro: We stayed here for 7 nights during 2017 Christmas and LOVED it!Getting to the hotel:Its just a 15 min ride from the airport to the Inn. We rented a car which we picked up on the airport, it was very convenient and quick. The Location:The inn is located in a quiet residential area just outside of the Waikiki beach. It is definitely possible to walk down to the city center, which we did once and it took us about 30 min, but bare in mind that most of the walk was slightly downhill. We do however recommend to take a car/taxi to and from the Inn if you want to go to the beach or go for shopping. It takes approximately 10 minutes by car from the Inn to Waikiki. We quite enjoyed the location of the Inn, is super relaxing and quiet, no tourists no crowds. The room:We booked the AS Cooke room which we were super happy with, its located on the second floor and was the perfect size for 2 adults. The room is decorated in the same manner as the rest of the house, its victorian, authentic and very charming. The bed was comfortable and the air-condition was more than adequate. The room also has a separate wardrobe and a bathroom with a separate shower room. Unique détails:Don't expect a modern boutique hotel with an victorian interior! This is a historic house with genuine charm, fantastic garden and a salt water pool. The Inn keepers were super friendly but not intrusive. It really feels like your visiting someones home. A big plus for us was the 4 dogs, Peace, Donkey, Yoda and DaVinci. Super friendly, loving and happy keepers of the inn that really added an extra charm to this Inn for us. Good to know:There is free parking on the grounds. Breakfast is both a small buffet and eggs/pancakes on order. The dogs are not in public areas all of the timeThe property is placed on the national register of historic placesThe hotel is organic!Overall impression:Great! we loved it!We would definitely stay here again due to the charm of the house and the relaxing atmosphere. Keep in mind that it's also very convenient, you don't have to worry for parking, you don't have to pay for parking. Waikiki and shopping is just a short car ride away. But the best thing is that its organic and environmentally friendly. Be smart!

Beautiful house with plenty of room but the furnishings and entrance door are in a need of cleaning. Breakfast was very good. Staff was very friendly. We were asked if we needed our room made up, which is very unusual. I was to make the bed!! The gardens were lovlely but overgrown and in need of a cleaning.

review_body: This is a lovely and unique bed and breakfast inn. We were visiting the University of Hawaii and this was a perfect location. The hosts are very welcoming and helpful, and the breakfasts on the terrace are delicious. We also enjoyed the family pets and the beautiful garden. It was like a home away from home.

My wife and I have stayed at the Manoa Valley Inn severral times. We love everything about it. The staff is amazingly helpful and great people with good family values. We really felt like we were right at home. We love how romantic the property feels. Eating a home cooked breakfast in an amazing garden is something you can experience everyday here. In the afternoon we like to take a relaxing swim in their secluded lagoon style pool. AMAZING!

This hotel was better than I expected! Our flight arrived very early and there was no problem in letting us join in on the breakfast, even though we were only staying for 1 night (and therefore got two breakfasts). The service was top notch and the breakfast exceptional. The location is very quiet in a residential area and a short uber right to Waikiki etc. Best of all, the price was completely reasonable and lower than a lot of hotels in the area. I would definitely recommend this B&B!

Delightful B&B near the University of Hawaii, so hidden by gardens and shrubbery that drivers had trouble finding it. Beautiful old house, lovely garden, good breakfast. There are dogs -- friendly, mostly well-behaved ones, but still, if that's a problem, this is not for you.

We love this spot just outside of downtown Honolulu, as well as the personal care with guests and the historical property. This is a special place for us, and we love the Guild Suite and breakfast on the lanai.

A completely terrible place. Disgusting smell all over the house. The restroom in the bedroom I was, did not have a shower, just a tub that I couldn't stand, the ceiling was really low, I could barely stay in it crouched, pathetic place. Carpets all over with disgusting stains. Just a complete nightmare, I left as soon as I could. Oh, the breakfast was disgusting too, I don't know how, but they were able to make bacon look completely disgusting: it was basically raw and really old, mixed with large chunks of purple cabbage (yea... for breakfast). Everything else was old: breads and fruits.

My wife and I were delighted with our first time in Hawaii, and our stay at Manoa Valley Inn contributed to our enjoyment.We considered staying downtown (about two miles away) in some of the more expensive resorts, but were deterred by the daily parking charge. We realized that we made a great decision to stay away from all the action once we arrived. It is fun to head downtown during the day or night, but even better to leave the noise and commotion and come back to a quiet refuge.We stayed in the Master Guild room. It was very spacious and the bed was comfortable. The decor was old. The TV was probably bought last century. There were at least three other couples, but we didn't hear them.Breakfast was tasty and made to order. Coffee at 7am, cooking by 7:30am. We could eat with other guests in main area, or bring the food upstairs to another sitting room.If you plan on bringing a car, consider one of a smaller variety. The parking situation is limited. We always had a space to park, but it was harrowing to enter or exit the grounds with the Mustang we rented.We enjoyed walking the grounds of University of Hawaii. There are a few local eateries and pubs, but for more choices, plan on walking, biking or driving at least a mile.Also, we are dog people, so reacted positively to the two dogs (one small, one large) that roam the inn. They appear trained not to go upstairs to the guest rooms.Overall, we felt positively about the Manoa Valley Inn. Should we ever stay in Oahu again, we will likely stay there again.

I had to fly over to Hawaii for a very quick business trip and needed to find something for 4 days at the Government daily lodging rate. I came upon the Moana Valley Inn and was surprised at the nightly rate - knowing that it included breakfast and free parking. I should mention that this B&B is literally right around the corner from The University Of Hawaii campus in a quiet neighborhood. It is off the beaten path, but only couple minutes from the H1 and perhaps 10 minutes from downtown Waikiki. Since my work took me closer to the airport everyday, it was most important to have immediate access to the highway.This 1880's mansion is fantastic and has all its old fashioned charm in the bedrooms and bathrooms as well as the rest of the public areas of the house. Our breakfast was served every morning outside the back door on a very nice veranda. That area was so quiet and tranquil which lended itself to only quiet chatter amongst the guests (library quiet)...Our hosts served a Japanese interpretation of Breakfast - that was delicious. On the first day, the bacon was steam cooked together with kale. Different but very tasty. The second day was Portuguese sausage medallions steamed with cabbage. Again, very tasty. Instead of pan seared, the potatoes were more like baked potatoes cut into quarters and covered in black pepper from a pepper grinder - delicious but different. Our hosts also offered made to order organic eggs and pancakes.Juice, Fresh fruit and pastry options were awesome; coffee and tea were great. Oh, the Inn has a fantastic swimming pool behind the house that can only be described as a hidden paradise. More like a place for meditation and relaxation than anything!Parking is free at the Inn (downtown hotels average $10-15 daily for parking) but spots are a little tight. If you are driving here from the airport, go for a compact or Economy car. Needless to say, I will be back to the Manoa Valley Inn!!!

During our travel around Oahu someone asked us which tower we were staying in. If you prefer resort-style accomodation and want to stick with the crowds then try somewhere else but if you would like a personalised stay in Hawaii and you just want to relax then this is the place for you. Our flight landed in the early morning. Through prior arrangement, our hosts happily agreed to let us chill out by the pool before our room was ready. We were hoping for a couple of sun lounges so we could catch up on a couple of hours sleep but as the picture shows, we found something better. Everything isn't pristine but this is an old building, with old Hawaii charm. We prefer something with character and this accommodation certainly has that. Our room was clean and comfortable and breakfast was ample. We had a hire car so getting around wasn't a problem but, this place is close enough to the H1 that you are soon on your way to your destination. Our hosts were attentive but discrete - there were little touches everywhere that signalled there efforts to ensure their guests enjoyed a peaceful stay!p.s. hire the cheapest car from the major car companies because the minimum class appears to be convertible mustangs!

I traveled for a business trip and the Manoa Valley Inn made a good home base. Quiet and peaceful. Although the downstairs initially gave me pause due to a strong aroma of mothballs, the rest of the inn didn't suffer the same issues. I stayed in the Dole suite and my room was pleasant, clean and comfortable. Other reviewers have noted the odd shower (a sit down bathtub situation) which I didn't love, but I did appreciate having my own bathroom. The hosts were very gracious and welcoming. The mini-fridge in the third floor hallway (shared between the three upstairs rooms) was a nice touch. My day started early, so I only had breakfast twice (it was served from 7:30-9). I wouldn't say it was a standout experience, but it was fine.

Outstanding old world and real world. Treat yourself to a walk back in time. Felt like being invited into your ancestor's home. The gardens feel so private with wonderful discoveries to make in every nook and cranny.

review_body: Super clean, good breakfast, garden and pool area are superbes. Beautiful old house (115 years+). We definitively recommand this place. About 10 minutes of Honolulu downtown with many restaurants within 2 miles.

A great place for a romantic getaway! Highly recommend it. A beautiful garden and pool. Delicious breakfast. Gracious hosts. Elegant throughout. The guest rooms are spacious and lots of attention to details. Overall an enjoyable relaxing place to spend with that special someone!

A beautiful Victorian house on the National Registry. Each room is uniquely decorated with antiques. Breakfast is served on a wonderful lanai. They offer fruits, juice, coffee, tea, two hot items (a meat and potato) then they will cook an egg and pancake if you wish. The Inn is tucked in quiet lower Manoa by University of Hawaii. A delightful place.

The Manoa Valley Inn Bed and Breakfast was wonderful! The family who assisted us while there were very friendly. The decor was very interesting, unique, and memorable- in a great way. The breakfast was delicious! Thanks again!

The house must have been glorious when it was built. The owners occupy the lower level and they have 7 rooms in the 2nd and 3rd floor. No elevator. Parts of the staircase have no handrail. The lower level stinks from the huge dog they have. The sinks are old, the shower is in the tub which has nothing to hold on to. The room we were in has beautiful antique furniture. One day when we were in the room we found a huge cockroach, disgusting. The breakfast is very good: fruits, 3 kind of breads, rice, two warm dishes, eggs and or pancakes made to order, juice and coffee or tea. There is parking on the property but is very tight.

My husband and I stayed here for a business trip. We found this place available and decided to book it for the free parking and free breakfast and it was away from all the hustle and bustle. The breakfast was amazing and sitting out on the lanai was nice and like we were in the jungle. We enjoyed the quiet peaceful setting. The place is a old historic building so it is very antique and it is decorated as so. We stayed in the cooke room which was decent but our bed was very lumpy and lopsided and the bedding was scratchy and old. The bathroom had watered down soap so I do recommend bringing your own soap, you won't have the regular hotel luxuries here. The pool was too cold to swim in but seemed very nice. It is a saltwater pool. Besides the bed though we enjoyed our stay. If you are looking for a decent price, quiet area, and free parking and breakfast, stay here. The staff were very friendly and we would stay here again.

Stayed there Oct 5-10, 2016 and loved it. It's on the historic register and so it should be. Even though it is historic it has all the modern amenities including Wifi and air conditioning. Quiet neighborhood, lovely breakfast. Duncan their 150 lbs. St. Bernard's dog is a treat too especially for dog lovers such as myself. Parking is not an issue as they have several spaces on their property. Staff were wonderful too-they let us check in early and check out late. Can't beat it. Douglas and Eileen Boyd

Charming Historic Register experience. Lot's of stairs and not much a/c. Serve yourself buffet breakfast and they make eggs and pancake to order. Lovely old building.Tiny sign makes it a challenge to find. Ask locals for help. Hopeless after dark.

Love old historic places. Great fresh breakfast. The issue we had was that no matter which room or even outside, there were huge flying roaches! It would be good to get rid of. Yes, it is near the jungle but if the garden in the back did not look like a overgrown crowded jungle, perhaps the roaches would be next to nothing. I seriously suggest the owner to do more for bug control. Saw them crawling everywhere at breakfast...inside and out.

I'm having a similar experience to another reviewer who had stayed here many years ago and who seemed to wrestle with some fundamental issues of fairness when comparing the current Manoa Valley Inn with what it once was. The inn's ownership over the past thirty years has changed a number times. It even faced possible demolition at one point though it now appears to be on a stable track of restoration and upgrade by the current owners. Most b&b and old house lovers understand that infrastructure issues like foundation, plumbing and wiring have to have a high priority in order for the structure to survive. They require heavy investment and patience. That patience likely won't extend to the average guest, hence my current classification of the Manoa Valley Inn as most appropriate for the niche B&B guest or old house lover. One exception to that is probably the couple who are looking for a romantic hideaway with distance from the hustle and bustle of today's Honolulu. Hard to quantify it, but old ornate rooms, beautiful landscaping and intimate surroundings provide a magic that many couples find intoxicating.Lots of seasoned b&b guests will know what to expect, or what not to expect from historic inns. Others, as evidenced by a number of reviewers, will start off with unrealistic expectations based on four or five star hotel properties. Resort enthusiasts should understand what to them may seem stark realities:There is no one waiting at the front door or in the main hall for your arrival. They will have to be alerted by a knock on the staff quarters door or through contact with other guests, if nearby. There is no bellman or staff to help with luggage. This is no small issue for older travelers as all of the rooms are on either the second or the third floor requiring a steep ascent up a lengthy staircase.The relatively peaceful neighborhood isn't far from Honolulu's many attractions, near the University of Hawaii campus. I wasn't too concerned about a lack of signage since I had done some detailed Google Earth searches and I knew what to expect, but not everyone will have done that.The inn's backyard is a verdant garden space of lovely tranquility. Sadly the property has been crowded by additional housing in recent decades resulting in a near total loss of the classic Waikiki / Diamond Head view from the inn's southerly facing breakfast lanai. Rooms on that side of the inn, especially on the third floor, still have that wonderful view. The garden-like surroundings of the backyard have been enhanced substantially, so the skyline of hotels may not be visible from the lanai, but the plantings and green space make for a tranquil haven. The small landscaped swimming pool in back, which was added in a more recent era, is a nice added amenity with an enticing romantic atmosphere.Now a few negatives: Breakfast was a mixed bag, heavy on vegetables and starches. The fruit was very good, but not exactly in abundant supply, especially if you arrive during the latter part of breakfast. The offer of egg OR pancake struck some in my family as decidedly less than opulent. Egg OR pancake? REALLY, at these rates? This could have been the result of a linguistic variation in the accent of our Japanese-American host staff member. Either way, the requested over-easy egg came out fried harder than the pancake would have been. One final note on breakfast: Nothing is more subjective than music and the background music played during breakfast no doubt is meant to enhance the calming, Zen-like atmosphere. We don't think they need a DJ to spin oldies for eating our egg and rice, but our family found the music more than a bit melancholy and heavy-handedly new-age-ish.Be forewarned that some family groups will pay a premium for a stay at MVI since none of the rooms can accommodate mom and dad and two grown children in their twenties. Since the inn makes no adjustment for such parties, you're looking at two full room charges which will put you over the luxury high rise rates for a room with a couple of queen beds.The two rooms we had were clean and met our basic expectations. The bedding and decor are badly in need of an upgrade. The plumbing all worked with plenty of hot water. The shower had some slow drainage issues, but was not a big problem. The classic old, still-functioning fixtures are a great reminder of times gone by. Our check-in and arrival instructions had been basic as well, leaving it to us to figure out by the second of our three nights there, that the rooms DID in fact have a form of air conditioning. The wall remotes in each bedroom controlled a wall-mounted cooler that restored comfort in short order. But you shouldn't have to figure out the controls yourself.There's always a balance at b&b's with too much or too little interaction with staff or owners. Once we had our keys, we didn't see the staff except at breakfast. We never did see the owner that I'm aware of. That would be exactly what many guests would want: near absolute seclusion with staff available if you need them. This is a big difference with a hotel concierge and room service that prospective guests need to understand.Word was that once some of the big ticket infrastructure issues were addressed, the rooms would be upgraded next. Sorry we couldn't have seen the post-improvement MVI interiors. It's heartening to think that the gorgeous Manoa Valley Inn will again shine as it once did.

This is one of my trickier reviews! Myself & my wife first visited Manoa Valley Inn some years ago & enjoyed our visit. We decided to spend a couple of nights there during our most recent visit.On the plus side - this is a tranquil, reasonably priced Inn overlooking Waikiki & Diamond Head. It has a very zen feeling about it & a peaceful atmosphere - we found it the perfect place to spend our first couple of nights in Honolulu, recovering from jet lag after a long journey. We were not quite ready to face the hustle & bustle of Waikiki. Lovely views accompanied by a beautifully serene atmosphere is what you get here. Very pleasant staff who cannot do enough for you, breakfast included -eggs to order + fresh fruit, juices , coffee , pastries taken in the garden. On the negative side- the Inn does need some tender love & affection- wallpaper , rugs & general decor are past their sell by date. It would not take much to bring this 100 year old house back up to a five star Inn.The decor is a bit kitsch , indeed odd, in many cases. We booked the Davies room on the 3rd floor - I think this is probably one of the best with great views of Diamond Head & Waikiki. Also, we slept with the windows open - lovely, soothing breezes.I can quite understand negative reviews but if you accept that this is a quaint, 100 year old property that is decorated in a rather haphazard fashion but which is a well priced, peaceful , tranquil oasis in which to spend a couple of days then I think you will enjoy the experience

My wife and I stayed at the Manoa Valley Inn for 2 nights during our trip to Oahu.We liked the fact that it was away for the busy areas of Honolulu.We opted for the Dole Junior suite. From the description, we knew the view wouldn't be as good as some of the more expensive rooms, and we were fine with it.But what we couldn't tell from the description or the pictures was that the bed would be so uncomfortable, and that you would have to be a contortionist in order to use the bathroom.The Dole room is on the top floor, under the roof and there is no way to stand in the tub in order to take a shower!! You have to bend in half in order to use the toilet or get into the tub, and after a bad night sleep, it would be nice to at least be able to get a good shower. Nope.On a much more positive note, the breakfast (included) is great! Eggs, rice, pastries, bacon/sausage, fruit, homemade pancakes, etc!!In summary, if you want to stay at the Manoa Valley Inn, don't cheap out, and ask for a room on the 2nd floor. I don't know if the bed will be more comfortable, but at least you should be able to stand in the shower!!

The property was quite old, being around here for about 100 years and is listed on National Register of Historic Places. I love antique furniture and do not mind a bit of shabbiness while traveling around, so I liked the Inn quite a lot. But it may not be the right place for you if you are seeking modern comfort with just a touch of Victorian style. Despite the number of stars this property has got, this is still a family-run B&B, not a full-service hotel. For me, I felt a bit like staying at grandma's home (happens my 94-yr granduncle used to live in the same area ages ago) and went all nostalgic. The breakfast was good as well in the same manner. Nothing flamboyant but robust. Pancakes were especially awesome!

Our group reserved two rooms, both were smelly, musty and dusty. Our rooms were on the third floor, no elevator, and parts of the staircase did not have handrails. Bathroom facilities were primitive. Pillows smelled musty; bedding and towels had never seen hot water or bleach. Signage for the Inn was difficult to see…we located it by process of elimination. No staff could be found when we decided to check out after one night so we had to carry our own baggage down the two flights of stairs. Certainly did not meet the expectations set by their listing. If we could have found staff when we left, we would have requested a refund. Don't waste your money! Disgusting!

My husband and I recently got married in Honolulu. We now live on the mainland, but both our families still live on Oahu. We hotel hopped during our 2 1/2 week stay, so we experienced all different types of accommodations. We booked the Master Suite for the night before and night of our wedding. This is one of the larger rooms, but also the most expensive, as it includes a separate sitting room. Hotels in general are quite expensive on Oahu. Manoa Valley Inn doesn't have additional parking fees, resort fees, and includes breakfast (which was quite good and free), so it's a great value once you consider all that. But be advised that this place is older. There was ongoing construction when we stayed there at the end of May, which limited parking and during the day construction workers would walk past your windows. Because of this, management gave us a discount, which was great customer service! Also, if are allergic or have a fear of dogs, be aware that there are two dogs on the premises, one being quite large. Both are friendly though and are only on the first floor. I enjoyed our stay here, but things are dustier, have more character. I would also not advise those traveling with kids to stay here as there are a ton of knick knacks everywhere.

If it wasn't for the outstanding, responsive and sympathetic customer service, I would rate this place horribly. After a snafu with rooms & construction, Manoa Valley definitely tended to our concerns as best as they possible could. I appreciated their efforts. This place is definitely an antiques-lovers dream/photographer's heaven because it captures and embraces the "old world Victorian" feel. The grand suite is definitely the one to book if you're staying here. It has a/c, a sitting room, and plenty of space. I would avoid the dole junior "suite" if at all possible. There's no shower and if you're male, u won't be able to pee standing up.The breakfast is definitely superb and unique...fresh papayas, pineapples, mangoes, eggs made to order, fluffy pancakes with local jam made to order, sausages, bacon, pastries, and interesting twist of Japanese/Hawaiian items like rice & stew. Yum!!!

Highly recommended and would stay there again. Room was well appointed and clean. Janice, the proprietor, is meticulous about her B&B and pays attention to detail. Minuses: the tub/shower were in the room with the bed and not private (behind a door that could be closed). Only one chair at a small desk (not enough room for a second chair). Otherwise the room was quite comfortable. Pluses: Breakfasts were gourmet and delicious. Free convenient parking, Wi-Fi, satellite TV, snacks/beverages. The air conditioning was quiet (good for sleeping).

This inn is very rundown and lacking the basic amenities. There's construction/renovation going on and workmen walk by the bedroom and bathrooms windows early in the morning and there's no privacy with the flimsy window curtains. There's no one to greet guests when they arrive and there's no effort to help guests with any sevices. Location is not walkable to beach/downtown. Musty smell in rooms and windows are closed up which exacerbates the problem. Pictures on web site are VERY misleading. Hard to understand how the charges can be only slightly lower than the posh hotels down on the beach. Would not recommend this inn.

This is a small bed and breakfast that is on a hill a short distance from Waikiki which provides a great night view of the skyline. Breakfast was very good, filling and complete to include fresh fruit which was set up in the lush garden. The staff was very friendly. Laid back and quiet but close to everything.Below it is asked about the area around the hotel. It is a quiet neighborhood but only about 1.5 miles straight down to the restaurants, beach etc. of Waikiki

I stayed here 20 years ago and remember it being a lovely B&B then. They don't seem to have done anything towards upkeep since then and the new owners are indifferent at best to issues of service. There is no one present to answer questions; when I arrived after a 9 pm flight in, the key was not left for me as promised; the rooms are not made up at all after arrival unless you phone the manager and ask that your room be serviced; internet is very slow and not available in some rooms; there are actually some holes in the walls of the Moore room, where I stayed. It's like staying in the run-down home of an eccentric and absent great aunt. Breakfasts are ok but not great and sometimes a bit sparse. English-language communication is not always easy with the people who are present to make breakfast and after that there seems to be no management available to answer questions, provide directions or suggestions for dining, etc.

When I was in college, I lived in a student coop whose tone was set by aspiring hippies. If we had opened a B&B, it would have been this.That has up sides. The old house is cool. The old furniture is cool. The garden is cool.But it also has exactly the downsides my imaginary coop hotel would have had.I spotted a couple of cockroaches, one in the shower, and one on my luggage. These werethe southern-sized (i.e., large) cockroaches.I got sick from eating the breakfast, the kind of sick that's usually due to sanitation issues.At about 1:00 a.m., water started coming down from the ceiling, fortunately not directlyon the bed or my bags or my computer. There wasn't any front desk to notify (there wasa sort of super's apartment, but they didn't respond to a knock on the door); no phonein the room. The next morning, I *may* have managed to explain what happened... or maybenot: the staff's English isn't quite good enough to communicate with. (I think their nativelanguage is Japanese, so if you're a Japanese speaker, that'd be a plus.)And of course there was little randomness -- e.g., the light next to the bed didn't work. (Thatlittle chain pull cord was gone.)For me, all of this was hippy nostalgia, and *almost* charming. But also, well, kind of a drag.So, if you have a high tolerance for hippy shabby, and think of it as nostalgia or tourism,*maybe*. (This place is just off the university, and the location might justify staying here,if you have business at the university.) If you're already a grownup, and you need thebasic functionality of a hotel (no rain in your bedroom, a front desk), you'll want totry elsewhere. (In any case, don't eat the food.)

Manoa Valley Inn was a sensory and visual delight. The mansion is filled with antiques that delight the mind. My room was large and comfortable: the furniture exquisite! The breakfasts were served on fine china and the food was plentiful and wonderful. The staff made this 65 year old solo traveler feel at home. The location is close the many fine restaurants and Diamond Head. The swimming pool and cabana is charming. This is a must stay inn! I am looking forward to my return.

It's a very long flight from Florida to Honolulu and when you get here you just want to relax and take a shower. Had a conference at UH Manoa and this was the closest accommodation. Internet page looked great so our corporate travel dept booked us here. Really bad mistake. This is not the place for you if you expect comfort and service. It is a beautiful old home but it is not really kept up- windows open-don't open-slam shut and you will need them as there is no air conditioning That's fine if you are on vacation and can wear shorts and tank tops but not if you need to wear business clothes. The rooms are dusty and the sheets don't look clean - don't try the comforters. My colleague was on the third floor with non opening windows and no shower. I at least had a shower with no light but decent water pressure. Don't book this based on the website. They also won't let you cancel under two weeks in - we only made the reservations a few days before we left but were told even though the place was not comfortable and we didn't like it that it was too bad for us we had to pay the entire stay. Lesson learned. We will tell our corporate travel group this is not the place to put people - though folks staying in Waikiki who want a non chain hotel experience and who can appreciate the lack of modern comforts will probably enjoy it.
