review_body: Reside in a grand arts and crafts bungalow perched in the upper valley of Manoa overlooking Waikiki (at a far distance) and Diamond Head. Cool breezes and rapidmists swirl about this remarkable historic building while one settles into a deep embracing porch with a great cuppa, local fruit and the paper. Period rooms recall the turn of the century, and although they're a wee bit musty, the bed was comfortable and the ambience of fans and cross breezes enhanced a relaxing stay. Highly encouraged for those who love architectural history and enjoy browsing through a long ago neighborhood.

Hard not to gush being fresh off the plane. This is the third time I'd stayed here and compared to when it was run by a Japanese management team back in the 90's it has a much warmer feel now. John and Theresa are great hosts who leave you be but are available when needed. We felt like we were at home with our own bedroom and a bathroom down the hall. Had some great conversations on the lanai out back and spent a lot of time in the pool area which is richly landscaped and has a very private feel. They have done a great job with the grounds, the overall landscaping helps you forget you are right in a neighborhood and the views of Diamond head from the lanai are great.We stayed in the Dole room (which utilizes a common bath) over Labor day weekend. Access to the The Bus and everywhere else is pretty good since you don't have to wait in Waikiki traffic to get around the island. Further to the previous post, we could hear the neighbors but the noise is less than most Waikiki properties and it was little kids playing (it is in a neighborhood afterall). We personally loved the outdoor veranda focus of the common areas since we wanted to be outdoors the whole time.The recommendations for Paesano's italian restaurant and the Wai-Oli tea room were excellent as well.

The last 2 reviews seem very harsh. The back porch and yard are gorgeous with a breathtaking view of the Waikiki skyline. The backyard has gardens and a small pool that are great for unwinding at the end of the day. We had no trouble talking to the owners or other guests, who offered us some great tips for sightseeing. Breakfast was nothing special...could use some improvement there. The room had Victorian furnishings and a comfortable bed. There was no air conditioning in our room which made it a little warm and humid for us, since we are used to the dry air of Las Vegas.

We came here to vacation with friends. the Inn is very nice and peaceful. The rooms are perfectly adequate and each room has a bathroom and shower. Breakfast was so so. the owners are very nice and helpful when it comes to helping you plan your day, where to eat, park, etc. You have a beautiful view of downtown and Diamond Head from the back porch.

We stayed here as a way to avoid Waikiki and support the local economy/small business. Plus, I used to live in Waialua and Kaneohe, and so was looking forward to coming back to a neighborhood. Ok, so here's the bad: - The people are strange. They don't seem like B&B people (read: not friendly). They have walled off the lower portion of the house for their own use. I understand doing that for some of the house, but when you walk down the stairway, you have nowhere to go but outside (where they want you, is my guess) because the doors to the left and right are closed. This alone makes this B&B untenable, in my view: there's no real common space to play games, meet other people, etc. The semi-good: - The house is nice, and the backyard, where they have breakfast, is quite pleasant. In sum: nice neighborhood (except for screaming neighbors at one point in the middle of the night), old but beautiful house, but the vibe from theplace is so negative I'd never stay here again.

We have stayed at many quaint b&b's and love the idea of supporting local businesses while avoiding the tourist-hotel chaos. To our disappointment, this "historic" building has been sadly neglected and the owners appear utterly unconcerned. Duct tape on the front door, shabby bath towels for the beach and broken windows in the rooms are unacceptable. The service and accommodations were both sub par.

Such a disappoinment! Usually, I love staying at quaint guest houses and enjoying the home comforts that they offer. In this case, I regret not supporting corporate American where at least I can be assured that the room would be clean and are much more centrally located. The Inn is greatly in need of repair, the furniture is dusty and the mattress is of poor quality. The outdoor furniture and bungalow (specifically the sheets and pillows that hadn't been washed) are so dirty that we didn't want to sit on them (and we've lived in the third world). We asked the owner how to get to Pearl Harbor and other attractions and he could only offer a pricey cab option claiming that he didn't know public transport . Well, two blocks from his Inn is a direct bus that goes to Pearl Harbor, the beaches, and downtown all for $2.50 round trip! When I mention this to the other owner she said that she knew about the bus, but offered no apology that her husband could not provide the information. Luckily, every local and the bus drivers were all very willing to help us and provide good info even if the Inn could not.

We enjoyed our visit at the Manoa Valley Inn so very much. It was like home. When we arrived we realized we needed an additional room. Teresa and John were so kind they scurried to prepare an anitional room for my Grandaughter. We were all so comfortable and the breakfast was great. We spent so much memorible time in the garden, veranda, front porch and pool. We made some wonderful memories.

We happened upon the Manoa Valley Inn by accident. What a find it was. This historic home is just far enough away from Waikiki to feel like you are enjoying the "real" Hawaii. It is still close enough to be a tourist. After living in Hawaii for 4 years and coming back this was like coming to a home away from home. Theresa and John are the bomb. They are full of knowledge about the city. Even for those of us who think we know our way around. They treat you like family and want to make sure you see the true Hawaii. We recommend this to those of you who are coming to Hawaii for the first time and those of you who feel you know your way around the island. You will find Manoa Valley Inn the perfect place to relax and recharge after a day on the island. The pool is perfect for relaxing after that long day on the town. We loved our stay.......Sandy and Ed

My husband and I spent a week enjoying this quite and restful inn. The hosts, Theresa and John, are wonderful, friendly people who take great pride in their historic establishment. Recommended for those who want to get away from the over-crowded and noisy downtown Waikiki area. Mahalo Theresa & John!

I enjoyed my 2 night stay here. John and Theresa are welcoming and very interesting hosts.The serve yourself continental breakfast just enough to start the day.I loved it because it was so quiet, away from the city noise yet very convenient to restaurants and activities.

We spent six very pleasant days at Manoa Valley Inn during our stay on Oahu,as part or our around the world trip.John and Theresa were very helpful and accomodating and if we return to Hawaii again we will certainly stay at Manoa Valley Inn. If you are looking for bland overpriced international hotels then it would not be for you but if you are looking for old world charm and character and a good standard of service then we reccomend this inn unreservedly. Ian and Marianne Murray from England

This year, our third at the Manoa Valley Inn, saw us in the Cooke Room, a large space with a king-sized bed, a ceiling fan and its own bathroom within this house that is on the historic registry on the island of Oahu. Breakfasts on the veranda are a lovely way to start the day, sitting at one of many little tables in the shelter of the spacious porch overlooking a garden that is in perpetual bloom and with a view of Diamond Head and Waikiki. The Inn is minutes away from the H1, across from the lovely campus of the University of Hawai'i. We saw more local places of interest this year thanks to the information imparted by the knowledgeable hosts, John and Theresa. We eagerly anticipate another stay next winter.

It is a quaint B&B with lots of history and friendly service. Due to the humitity it reminds me of how clean an old cabin by the ocean would feel. My formost complaint is the lack of disclosure on how many rooms / people share bathrooms. We were told and I quote "WE DO HAVE A ROOM WITH TWOBEDS, PRIVATE BATH ROOM FOR $145 PER NIGHT. OR A ROOM WITH A SHAREDBATHROOM, TWO BEDS SHARING THE BATHROOM WITH ANOTHER ROOM." but in reality there is a toilet and sink by the main door (does NOT lock and only a lace curtain to the front veranda). The second floor has NO bathroom, you go up or down for use of a bathroom! The third floor has a 3 piece bathroom the ONLY SHOWER for all 5 rooms which each holds 2 to 4 people... you do the math!! I do not know if the main floor bathroom (similar to a bad gas station) was ever cleaned more then once a week and the third floor was only cleaned ever second day (24 hrs with a pile of towels).

Quiet historic house but not what I expected from an American B&B.All furniture is dirty. The bed was terrible. On closer inspection it looked like theyhad not changed the sheets for a very long time,Dust was everywhere!The house was very shabby,the towels in our bathroom were probably bought in the '50s....Breakfast was sparse, no eggs, no ham.It wasn't a comfortable stay. I wouldn't recommend it and I wouldn't go back.

This place is an old, shabby, creepy, depressing victorian mansion. Bad need of upgrades and repairs. The first thing that got to me was the smell. Old, musty, dirty smelling. Made you want to run away and book someplace else. I've read other reviews and they said the exact same things I'm writing about. Room was dark, creepy, depressing, and hot. Ceiling fan did little to alleviate the heat. Lighting was very bad. I felt as if I was in that movie, Psycho. Bathroom mat was dirty and not washed for a new guest. Shower wall dirty, shower curtain/caddy had mold. Shower head was old, grimy and couldn't move. No light in the shower - had to shower in the dark. Sheets on the bed did not feel fresh, pillows old. They use that horrid plastic stuff under the bed sheet--I couldn't believe it! Ugly bed linen that shouldn't be used for guests any longer. Veranda was dirty and messy. Decor of the house is cheap, old, and creepy. I got attacked by bugs in bed every night. Don't know if they were bed bugs, fleas, lice, or mites. But they bit me and I was scratching at 2.45 am. Total rip off.

After years living in the neighborhood, I finally stayed as a guest at the romantic Manoa Valley Inn. Very helpful couple run the place; great place to chill out. Sleeping with windows open; great to wake up to the scent of plumeria flowers and chirping birds, but the occasional traffic / neighborhood noise -- mostly a fairly quiet neighborhood.. On-site parking if you have a rental car, which is nice. Salt water pool in the back yard, but didn't have a chance to use it.

This must be considered a hidden gem, it's funky and soulful, and nothing like the sterile boxes of Waikiki hotels,that are considerably more money and charge you for parking, where you hardly ever see or even get to chat with anyone, except a front desk clerk. Here you get to have breakfast on this beautiful veranda and meet and talk with people from all over the world, including the marvelous proprietors, Theresaand John, the Inn has been around since 1912, and is a unique experience, don't miss a chance for something truly different.

The house is a historical landmark with lovely rooms, a heated salt water swimming pool, a beautiful breakfast setting with a variety of fresh fruits, yogurt, breads and muffins served. The hosts were friendly, made us feel welcome, and were very helpful in suggesting restaurants we never would have found ourselves.

My husband and I stayed here for a week, and coming back to this warm and lovely environment after nights out in Waikiki was the highlight of our trip. My husband needed to work a few hours each day, and he did so on the furnished veranda amid breezes, flowers, and birdsong. While he worked, I read in the "tiki hut" cabana by their sweet little stone pool. The owners gave us plenty of advice, and wonderful service. They even provided coffee for my husband while he worked. I feel as though we've made friends for life.The Inn is not for everyone; some folks might be better off staying at a hotel chain where everything is cookie-cutter perfect. The Inn is not perfect, it is in an older home with most, if not all, of its original features intact. That means old-fashioned door locks and keys, beautiful craftsman details, older and sometimes sticky windows, and wallpaper that you won't find at your local Lowe's. I am a lover of old houses and these things are charming quirks to me that represent a real home instead of a sanitized white box of a room on the 23rd floor of some non-descript hotel chain.The lush gardens are amazing - not over-landscaped, the trees and flowers reminded me that I was in a tropical paradise. The pool is tucked out of site and so made me feel as if I were slipping off to my own secret paradise. Theresa and John were cordial and welcoming and concerned with our comfort and enjoyment. We will make Manoa Valley Inn our home away from home on Oahu from now on.

My wife and I just spent a week at the Manoa Valley Inn and it was one of the most restful, wonderful stays either of us can recall anywhere. The beautiful historic building, and the gorgeous garden and huge veranda, provide a lovely, quiet, retreat. At the same time, you can easily get to beach, highway, and downtown.The old fashioned rooms are a treat. We stayed in the smallest, i believe, the Sun Room and shared a bath. I have to say, as someone who spends 100 nights a year on the road for business, and is used to my own space, I was dreading this. Silly me! It was no problem, the bathroom was comfortable and clean and in the same grand style as the house, and all was well.Two real standouts: the veranda and gardens, and the hosts. I had to work most mornings while there, but doing so on that deck, which i had to myself even though the place was full, made it as painless as it could be. My wife spent time at the perfectly sized (and heated) pool, and its unique cabana bed for napping, and we enjoyed all this so much that one afternoon we simply hung out there instead of packing up and heading to the beach!Theresa and John are great hosts as well, accommodating, friendly, and a tremendous source of recommendations for hikes, beaches, restaurants, and more.We really cannot imagine having had a nicer time, and surely will return as soon as we can.

Not what I expected from an American B&B. Although it was cheap and the hosts were very nice, the house was very shabby, fan wasn't working in room, TV remote missing, plumbing very noisy and breakfast was sparse. It wasn't a comfortable stay. I wouldn't recommend it and I wouldn't go back.

AWESOME! My husband and I spent two weeks over the holidays at the Manoa Valley Inn and highly recommend it to others. John and Theresa are attentive hosts giving good advice on delicious eateries and visiting the Islands hidden treasures. The location is close to everything, yet feels worlds away from the garish hubbub of Waikiki. The view while eating breakfast on the lanai is unmatched. We especially enjoyed the beautiful gardens and swimming in the lushly landscaped pool. The Baldwin Room was comfortable, pleasant and had lots of interesting Victorian furnishings, as did the entire B&B. MVI is a relaxing & beautiful place to stay when visiting Oahu. We hope to return.

My wife and I stayed stayed at The Manoa Valley Inn for a week. It truly became our home away from home. The owners Teresa & John make their home a VERY special place for Hawaii travelers.This B & B is an historic home with beautiful grounds. The beds are comfortable, the showers are nice and strong and the views from the rooms look onto downtown Waikiki. There is a beautiful veranda where you can enjoy a good cup of coffee and relax. There's wi-fi and plenty of places to sit back and stay in touch.There's also a nice pool on the grounds to relax in. Teresa & John are extremely helpful with all of one's questions and they go out of their way to help you and make you feel comfortable.If you are looking for a little jewel to stay at that's away from the hustle and bustle of Waikiki, this is the place!I'll definitely keep coming back.

Our trip to Hawaii was enhanced by Manoa Valley Inn. From the beautiful victorian rooms to the warm morning conversation on the viranda with owners and guests, the experience at this getaway made our honetmoon feel like paradise. It is isolated from the city below, yet still close by for convenience. The owners were like our own presonal tour guides for the best places to go during our stay. We recommend it and hope to return.

I had high hopes for this bed and breakfast, given options of large hotels in Waikiki but the stay was spotty. The first night was interrupted by police knocking on door of adjacent room and ongoing conversations there. Less than good quality sleep. Housekeeping also less than thorough, second night in another room there was dust on side table and dresser. Hosts appear to have good intentions. Charming buidling with victorian type furniture. I would not return, however.

The house was so beautiful. We slept well in comfortable beds. The outside porch displays the city lights so beautifully in the evening. We were treated like friends. We reunited with my husbands twin brother . We couldn't have asked for more. We can not wait to see you again.

Manoa Valley Inn was a treasure find at this poiint of my life. It was a haven of peace with hosts Theresa and John treating all guests with kindness, consideration and respect for their privacy, occasionally affording special accommodation to guests. I am happy that they treat their guests with a genuine spirit of Aloha from Hawaii.

For those who know the true meaning of Aloha; For those that give it and have received it, this is a wonderful stop on your trip. We booked three nights and stayed eight. Teresa and John are now friends and whether we stay with them or not, we will visit. John knows the Island and loves to help everyone find new places and have new adventures. We met guests from Germany and Canada while we were there. Another great part of the place.Breakfast on the lanai overlooking all of Waikiki and Diamond Head cannot get better. One can imagine what the view was like in 1912. All in all, a great experience.

It was my greatest pleasure recently to spend 3 nights at Manoa Valley Inn. Our accommodations were comfortable and clean and the house itself is a craftsman treasure. John and Theresa are gracious hosts. We loved the referrals to local eateries, avoiding the Waikiki crowds, and feasting on fine food with good company.

Great location. Manoa Valley Inn is close to town but you wouldn't know it. It's so peaceful. Got great recommendations for dinner every night. With their dogs running around it felt like being at home. The house is tucked away among plants and trees with a view of Diamond Head.

It was such fun to stay in this historic home in Manoa Valley. The breeze swept down through the valley every night and our hosts, John & Teresa gave us excellent tips on where to eat. We had fresh fruit, great coffee and bread and muffins every morning and sat around on the veranda in the late afternoon, enjoying a dip in the pool. The grounds are beautiful and it was a treat to explore an area other than Waikiki and get a sense of another Honolulu.We came over from the Big Island to play in a tennis tournament and we were not disappointed with our accommations!

Our family initially chose Manoa Valley Inn due to its close location to the University of Hawaii. The main purpose of our trip was to get our son settled in the dorm -- of course, we also took time to explore the island a bit while we were there. Manoa Valley Inn is a lovely historic inn that reminds you of a gentler time and place. I absolutely loved the quiet peaceful garden with the saltwater swimming pool. The back veranda and yard provided a welcome respite from lugging boxes to the fourth floor of our son's dorm. The owners offered good tips for local restaurants, services and attractions. In some cases, John told us exactly where to park and how much it should cost. (This was great for someone not familiar with the area.) A tip I would offer is to call their number before you show up for check-in. Although we'd made our reservations, there was no one home when we arrived at 5 p.m. in the afternoon. Since it's just Theresa and John, it's understandable how both could be out. A quick phone call ahead could've resolved this for us. I hope to come back to the Inn the next time we're in Oahu.

Service was very friendly and helpful, but also very unprofessional and at times completely absent.The room was fantastic and much more than we needed - but we weren't going to complain about the free upgrade we received. It had 2 downsides: the toilet made a quiet but obnoxious whining noise about once each day - flushing fixed it. And, the bed rested on several 2x4s on the frame and one fell out.The location is a bit far from the tourist side of Honolulu - but if you have a car rented or are fine with the buses or a little walking, it is just fine. It is right next to the college.Breakfast was fresh fruit and fruit juice and the porch on which it was served was fantastic. The pool is saltwater so it doesn't smell like chlorine.

This Victorian B & B was a great value and conveniently located near the university and bus lines. We had a rental car and getting to and from the airport was EASY. My daughter and I loved the unique decor of each room, the sweeping veranda and rustling of the tree leaves in the night breeze. John and Theresa (the owners) even arranged for a professional massage therapist to come to the inn that evening. Imagine the luxury of a 60 or 90 minute candlelight massage on the veranda with the scents, soothing sounds and warm moist Hawaiian air! This was a perfect finish to our vacation and certainly prepared our bodies for the long hours of flight back to Alaska. I shall certainly return.

Though we reside in Oahu, we were searching for a secluded place to celebrate our 35th Wedding Anniversary. We wanted something different yet special, romantic yet secluded from the city life surrounding us. This was a true find of all the many options available to us in Waikiki, North Shore & Makaha areas; we thought this was the best of all. It has such a surprise to it. Once you arrive you enter a world of the past with historic atmosphere & Hawaiian pictures & various touches throughout the inside & outside gardens, lanai, & views. It is so breathtaking to look out at this marvelous view & knowing that the city life is just a block away, but you cannot hear it!!! Then we were able to enjoy the pleasant welcome of the co-owner & were settled into our room, had some refreshment, a beautiful heated salt-water swim prior to our going out for dinner. The pool is nestled in a tropical ambiance of seclusion & beauty. It was very romantic & still remained in wonder at knowing the city was so close by, but felt as if we were in a mountain pool by ourselves. AMAZING!! We were able to return in the evening & go for another swim which was again so breathtakingly sweet & peaceful with romance in the air. The room we were given was so beautifully decorated, which gave it the feel of being in your own home bedroom, but nicer in that you don't have to do the clean-up. We were provided with breakfast on the lanai in the AM & then the option of roaming the garden area in back with foliage & flowers everywhere. We were thrilled & knew we made a most terrific find in this one night stay. We plan to recommend this to anyone who wants a VERY SPECIAL PLACE whether it be for a short stay or a long stay, I promise you. it will be worth it!! Simply put - ABSOLUTELY GORGEOUS & BEST!!!!

This B&B is located in a quiet neighborhood with handy access to the freeway & is walkable to the University. The rooms are large with antique furniture. Not every room has a TV if that is important.The pool, surrounded by tropical plants, was open to guests.A continental breakfast with fresh fruit, yogurt & muffins is served.The owners were charming.

Robert/ AnnWe stayed at Manoa Valley Inn during our visit to Hawaii in April and May. We really enjoyed staying at this beautiful, historic inn. The rooms are spacious and beautifully decorated. The very best part of the home is the lanai/porch which overlooks Waikiki Beach and Diamond Head. The grounds are impecable, and the pool, after a long day of sightseeing, is delicious! Theresa and John are wonderful hosts. They were so very helpful with directions, suggestions of great places to eat, and simply gracious hospitality.  Mahalo, Theresa and John for a wonderful visit to Manoa Valley Inn.

This is the perfect choice if you have any business at the University. Leave your car here and walk to every point on the campus in minutes. Parking on campus or anywhere near campus is a headache.We had seven family members staying here, and we rented three rooms. Each room was unique with its own antique furniture and art. We all found the beds to be comfortable and slept well. The house is big, and had a very large and private veranda on the back, overlooking a large yard and view of Waikiki and diamond head. I hope to find a picture to include in this review.What we all liked the best about staying here was the veranda. It has a wonderful view and is surrounded by flowers and tropical plants.A breakfast of coffee, juice, tea, fruit, yogurt, cereals,breads, muffins, etc. is served every morning on the veranda. Our charming hosts, Teresa and John, kept us and all of the guests entertained as we enjoyed the view, flowers,and birds. The only down side is we shared a bathroom on our floor, but even with our seven family we did not have a problem with it. Other rooms have a private bath, but they were taken.I thought the pricing was low for our stay, compared to everything else on Oahu and other B&Bs we have stayed at.Would like to come back again and enjoy that veranda!

My husband and I have stayed here a couple of times and we can't wait to go back to this beautiful B & B. We were attending my son's graduation from U. of H., Manoa. The location couldn't have been better. We had a short walk to the graduation ceremonies. The owners are warm and gracious. They present a healthy, delicious breakfast each morning on the back veranda which overlooks Waikiki. The gardens are beautiful, the swimming pool is equally beautiful. It is a quiet Bed and Breakfast, no noise issues even though it is close to the University. The bed was comfortable and we will happily book with John and Theresa again. It is close to Waikiki and Honolulu without the noise. Also, there is free on site parking!

I arrived with my friend -- that wrote the review below and is now calling the Manoa the Bates Motel -- with great anticipation. Since I have stayed in B&B's before I suggested rather than the hustle and bustle of Waikki for the first two days of our six days on Oahu, which was for both business & pleasure, to stay at the Inn. After her review I feel compelled to also write a comment.When no one answered the locked front door after at least three tries trepidation set in. Through the front door glass we could see a light on in the hallway and the owner's Jag parked in its marked spot. Figuring she might be out back we called her on her cell, and to our surprise she was in Maui having lunch and John, who we later learned is her boyfriend, was having lunch in Honolulu. Perhaps she forgot we were coming ?? We were given a code to take the key out of the lockbox to our room, but it was the key to the front door and not our room. So the owner's daughter was called to let us in and check the ledger for our room and give us a key -- it is about 1:30 p.m. in the afternoon -- and it turned out her mom had to wake her up to let us in. (She said she was 18). She showed us our room on the 3rd floor. There was no one there to help with the bags, though she did help my friend carry up one of hers. I asked about the provided breakfast and was told we had to let them know because not everyone eats it and they won't prepare it if you aren't going to be there and so we needed to sign in. I asked where to do that and was told that she would put a piece of paper out, but didn't really say where that would be.Once in the room we looked around and finally focused and really saw how dingy it was. Sure, the furniture is antique and the wood a little worn, which can be expected with antiques, but it wouldn't hurt to put some furniture polish on it to make it look clean. The plastic shampoo bottle on the dresser was foggy looking and tacky to the touch. The bedding looked worn and dingy/dirty and the room didn't smell exactly fresh. So we decided to leave. My friend told the daughter that we were leaving and we understood if we needed to pay for the first night. While carrying my bags down from the 3rd floor I saw the daughter in front of her room on the 2nd floor and she informed me that she spoke to her mother and that she would be refunding our money tomorrow as she is in Maui and John doesn't know how to do it. Don't know how John could have helped us since he wasn't even there. Thankfully I have a friend that lives about 3 miles up from the Inn and she helped us quickly find another hotel down by the zoo, which turned out to be just perfect. Instead of crediting my friend's card as promised for the pre-paid first night she was billed for a second night as well and is still awaiting credit. Another thing, we were told we were the only guests staying there which added to the uncomfortable feelings we were both having. That is why I wouldn't recommend this B&B until the "For Sale" sign in front says "Sold" and there are new owners. The house, with a facelift, has the potential to be magnificent.

We found the inn on line and it looked very nice. When we arrived there was no one there.We knocked 3 times, finally called owners cell phone she was in Maui she called her daughter to let us in. The place was so run down and moldy smelling. We had to call her back to find the rm we were staying in. We climbed to the 3rd floor and was agast at the aperance of the room and the beds and furniture.OMG I thought we were at the Bates Motel. We found it very erie. I asked for my money back had no idea it was so run down. She then charges my C.C. for an additonal nite. Still waiting for my credit

Theresa and John helped us feel completely comfortable in their 100-year-old National Register home. Shops and restaurants are a 15 min. walk away. The University of Hawaii, with its large bookstore, is a 2 minute walk. We arrived by cab from Waikiki (10 min.) and either walked or took the buses everywhere. We had no trouble getting around. One whole day was spent unwinding by their pool which has a lava rock waterfall. If you're into organic, healthy food, go to the Kokua Market. We were able to keep food in the small fridge on the verandah. What could be more special (and romantic) than sitting on the verandah enjoying wine and cheese while watching the sky darken and the evening lights of Waikiki coming on?

This hotel used to be a lot better and could be better again when John and Teresa have gone. For now I would NOT recommend staying there. The only public area, the verandah is shared with the family, including pets and children. There seemed to be no awareness of the guests, that they might want to be without teenage kids there. Teresa was kind of - how can I put this nicely - judgemental. SO not what you want in a holiday where you want to relax in a lovely hotel. When they manage to sell the hotel, and get someone running it who wants to be there, it might be good again. For now, you are better off staying in one of the university dorms nearby.

The inn is a little run down and there is only TV in some of the rooms but it was a nice setting. The pool was on the cool side but pleasant. The Lani was a wonderful place to read and has internet connection so we could relax and keep in touch if we wanted. The owner is a sweet lady and we may stay there again. Great location, out of the city but near to everything and the parking was FREE!!!

As an elderly woman who travels alone, I have stayed at the Manoa Valley Inn on several occasions over the past four years. And, indeed, it is my destination of choice when visiting Oahu. Elegant, clean, quiet, secure and friendly, it is centrally located yet removed from the hub-bub and bustle of Waikiki. Because it is situated in a residential area, it encourages morning walks around the area filled with attractive houses and winding streets. If one heads up the valley one can find a sizeable neighborhood shopping center. For location, ambiance and price the Manoa Valley Inn, in my opinion, can't be beat.

Being a long time customer of Bed and Breakfasts, I was looking forward to staying at the Manoa Valley Inn. Upon arrival I was stunned to find a house that was falling quickly into disrepair, but more importantly needed a thorough cleaning. The entire inn was filthy. Never before had I felt uneasy in a bed and breakfast because of its uncleanliness, but the Manoa Valley was just that for me. The carpet, floors, bath, windows, furniture and upholestry were downright filthy. A huge ashtray in the garden overflowed with cigarette butts. The breakfast plates and cups stayed outside on the veranda day after day after day. Trip Advisor in the past has provided consistent and sound advice on places to stay, however this time the good reviews did not square with my experience. It seemed that this place has been headed downhill for quite a while. A team of 10 would be needed to clean this place. The advertised wireless internet never worked in my room and was inconsistent at best in other areas of the house. One woman told me the inn overcharged her by $100 on her credit card, so beware. My advice: Stay somewhere else and have fond memories of Honolulu.

Our second stay at the Manoa Valley Inn, located in a Victorian house that is on the Hawai'i Historic Registry, provided us with a home away from home. We stayed in the same room as last year (the Moore Room). The difference for us was taking advantage of the lovely, small salt-water pool in the backyard. From the pool one can see beyond the flowering shrubs and flowers a view of nearby Wakiki and Diamondhead. Outside our window one could see the top branches of a huge, old mango tree laden with fruit, which the owners picked and served daily with breakfast on the verandah -- one morning we even had mango muffins, which were superb. The Inn is located so that all points of interest can be reached easily by car. The hosts are gracious and helpful as well as knowledgeable about the island's attractions. Although anyone looking for the amenities at a 5-star hotel right on the shore in Waikiki might be disappointed, the Manoa Valley Inn has been the place for us. The inn is for sale, and while we wish Theresa and John the best of luck, we hope we'll have at least another year there.

When we first saw the front of this B & B, we had some misgivings; the lawn was untended and ratty and a "For Sale" sign (one that had been tagged, no less) was hanging there. Those two things were the key to what it was like to stay there; we stayed six nights.This place has the potential to be a lovely B & B. It has a location near the University of Hawaii, and access to Honolulu/Waikiki is easy, but it's out of the hustle and bustle. It has a wonderful veranda that spreads across the whole back of the house with terrific views of Honolulu, especially at night. It's an old, original, huge Hawaiian house that's on the National Register of Historic Places.But the problem is that this place needs someone who actually wants to run this place to come in and take over. John and Theresa, the owners, have long since burned out on this place, and they're trying to get out. They're nice enough people, but they do everything themselves there, and they just don't want to do it anymore. Hence, the place is dirty, almost no service in your room, and the exact same breakfast every morning. Not only was our room dirty when we moved in, it was never vacuumed during our six days there, even though it obviously needed it. Your room is serviced only when you request it, and then only the minimum service possible. Theresa drives a Jag, and you can imagine how enthusiastic she is about scrubbing your toilet. We came in one day to find the bed made and all the dirty towels still on the floor of the shower.The room itself was not just dirty, the old Victorian furniture is tired and worn and cluttered looking. I never thought there could be such a thing as dead plastic flowers, but there is a vase of them on the landing to the second floor. And, there are no common areas in the B & B except for the veranda. The owners occupy the first floor and you aren't allowed into their areas, including the kitchen.The owners have two little dogs. One morning, as we were having breakfast on the veranda, one of the dogs proceeded to drop of pile of doggy-doo beside our table. Our breakfast was over for that morning. Two nights later we were walking up the landing to our second floor room and my girlfriend stepped in a pile of doggy-doo that one of the dogs had thoughtfully left us on the Oriental carpet. She was almost in tears over that one.Breakfast is served on the veranda and, while it's a lovely location, the breakfast consists of fruit, cereal, and bread, bagels etc., and coffee and tea. It was fine for a couple of mornings, but got old by the end. The owners claim and read the newspaper before they bring it out to the guests; would it really be too much expense to get two newspapers? The owners make no effort to do anything more than the minimum for breakfast. Or anything else, for that matter.At one point John came to me and told me that I had parked my car in "Theresa's space,"and asked me to move it. There was nothing to indicate in their tiny parking lot, that there was a reserved space for one of the owners, no "Reserved," or "Theresa's Space," we were just supposed to know that, I suppose.As much as I wanted to like this place, it desperately needs new ownership. It certainly isn't a 5-star establishment, maybe two stars at the most, and that's generous. I've stayed in some pretty great B & Bs, and this one is a failure on almost every level.

The setting is great! The house is on the historical list so it is on the older side but well taken care of. The porch area where you have breakfast is great. The porch area is also good for relaxing and surfing the net as well. The only criticism was that the breakfast options were somewhat limited. The owners were very friendly and helpful. If you have a car the Manoa Inn is well placed to a number of places according to what you want to do. If you are tired of the hotel setting and want another type of experience The Manoa Valley Inn is well worth checking out!!

The evening view is spectacular of the city lights. The moonlight swim was wonderful, as well as the cozy cuddle on the veranda. Breakfast on the veranda with the daytime view of the honolulu while meeting new friends was something we will want to experience again. Mahalo

if we will come back to hawaii we will come back to the manoa valley inn.we traveled to maui, big island and oahu. we enjoed this time very much. the stay in the manoa valley inn was the best hotel for us. the owners were very very nice. the view over honolulu, the quiet and the infos from john... much love from tine and tim from germany to john and theresa.

Located across from the University of Hawaii, close by the H1, this unique B and B offers a great place to sleep and have breakfast away from the beach but minutes from the roads to the beach. You could even use the excellent bus service on Oahu to go anywhere from a block away from here.The house has many interesting features inside and out. The terrace overlooks a great garden which connects to a small pool. Breakfast was very good with fresh fruit bowls and ample choices.Inside, you could expect to see Homes and Watson coming from the drawing room.The floors are dead quiet reflecting the solid building and upkeep. The third floor rooms will test your strength a bit carrying suitcases but on Hawaii, you only take them up once and down once.Outside of rush hour, an hour's drive to the top of the island either east bound (for the awesome scenery seaward and landward) or west bound (through the valley). Minutes from Ala Moana Center and Waikiki.
We really enjoyed our 2 nights in this b&b, the house is charming. Our stay was really pleasant and relaxing. Sophie and Stéphane (Belgium)

Myself and my husband Jim stayed here for about 10 days in April '09. The owners John & Teresa were very friendly and helpful. The B&B itself was very nice indeed. It is an old listed building which has been kept very well over the years. It was situated in a very beautiful area of Honolulu and within walking distance of most places. I was unfortunate to develop a chest infection when I was staying there and I am especially grateful to John for his herbal remedies and his advice while I was ill. Thanks John!If we were ever to go to Honolulu again I would have no hesitation in staying there again. We are from Ireland which is the other side of the world!! It was very expensive to travel there so it will probably be a long time into the future before we return to Hawaii!

Theresa, John and All - great hosts and made the stay more like ohana (coming from Kona). I've stayed at many B & Bs throughout the planet, but have to admit the Manoa Valley Inn is one of best Bed & Breakfasts I've experienced. On frequent trips to Oahu, they are my all time fav place to stay.Gracious, warm, peaceful, and beautiful, it is like an oasis located in Manoa's peaceful pali - with panoramic views of Honolulu's glittering lights.Mahalo nui loa & a hui hou (looking forward to coming back :))).

We arrived late at night and were given a warm welcome by Theresa. John & Theresa were a delightful host and hostess. The house is a charming old residence and will be 100 years old next year. It is furnished with antique furniture, in keeping with the age of the house, which gives it a restful ambience. The front of the house overlooks a magnificent, well maintained garden. The verandah, where breakfast is taken, leads onto the garden and to the swimming pool. If you want peace and quiet away from the bustle of Waikiki this is the place to stay. The local bus service is excellent and inexpensive.

Aloha Theresa! It´s been more than two weeks now, since we stayed one week at your Manoa Valley Inn and then went cruising with "Pride of America" for one week. I would like to thank you very much for having us that week! Both I and my daughters Anja and Linn enjoyed very much to stay at your hale Inn. The environment. The design. The quiet mornings with the very fresh breakfast that you and John made for us. For me it was a nice reunion (after five years) and for the girls it was a wonderful first time. I really appreciate all the advice we got from John. Even though we didn´t have the time to do all that he proposed for us. I hope we can come back one day (hopefully sooner than in five more years) and try to work on that list. We all hope that John had a wonderful birthday. Congratulations, even if it is a little late! I certainly enjoyed my birthday abord the "Pride of America". We had a wonderful week cruising around Kauai, Maui and Big Island. On my very birthday we had a fine dinner and also experienced the choir of the wine and food stewards at our table. I hope that everybody that apreciates culture in a quiet way will find their way to your place! All the best to you! Mahalo! And lucky you to be living in Paradise! Aloha from Anja, Linn and Tommy Karlholm in Stockholm, Sweden (Top of Europe)

This B&B is so quiet and blissful, situated in the nicest place to stay in Honolulu. Teresa and John feel, what their guests need. They are as charming as the location is. They are givers , not takers.We'll come again and we are going to recomend this guesthouse to all our friends, who come to visit Honolulu. Mahalo nui loa Teresa and John!

My name is Mario L. Cruz. and I am a high school teacher from San Bernardino, California. I was looking forward to a place for my winter break where I could really rest and enjoy some tranquility and it was here. The historic home offered an excellent bed and breakfasst service. I got a glimpse of history which expanded my understanding of culture and people. The facilitiies were in good condition. The managers and staff were very polite, respectful, and helpful. I strongly recommed the place to people who wants to spend their vacation in a serene environment and at the same time get easy access to the most stunning tourist spots in Hawaii. Needless to say, you will meet a very hospitable management staff.

Absolutely loved this B&B where we spent the first two nights of our honeymoon. Wanting to do something a bit different, we chose to stay in this beautiful home - listed on the national historic registry. Rooms were airy and bright, with antiques that made me feel I was in a very pleasant time warp. (we stayed in the Moore room) Lost, the TV show, just finished filming there the day we arrived. A bit over a mile from the crowded beaches, we still enjoyed the hustle and bustle of Waikiki, but then delighted that we were able to sleep in peace and quiet! Delicious papaya, croissants and pastries for breakfast. The proprietor Theresa was helpful and keeps the place up beautifully. Delighted that there were enclosed gardens with a lovely pool....wish we had more time there...but we had to head out to Volcanoes National Park! Mahalo!

My wife and I found out just prior to our arrival in Honolulu that our beachfront accomodations would not be available until the day after we arrived. I thought we might enjoy something a little different than the beachfront resort thing our first night, so I (somewhat nervously) reserved a night in the Davies Room at the Manoa Valley Inn in Honolulu, near the University district. We were not disappointed, and it was a beautiful, peaceful and comfortable one-night stay.The owner, Theresa, met us on check-in and kindly helped us with ice, and with information about the room, the grounds, breakfast, bottled water, etc., and we got settled into the room after a brutal day of travel--about fifteen hours' worth by the time we got to the Inn.The Davies Room is on the third (top) floor of this charming and historic Inn, and it has a private bathroom. (If you're really tall like I am, you need to be a little careful moving around in the bathroom and shower, or you can use the full-sized antique bathtub in the hall bathroom.) This room has a wonderful view of the expansive lights of Waikiki, but from a nice, quiet distance. We found the bed to be wonderful and extremely comfy, and the room was clean and very tastefully appointed. (I enjoyed the Maxfield Parrish print of "Daybreak" in our room... it's so full of peace and ecstasy.) The screened windows were all open when we entered the room and we left them open all night long. The peaceful sounds, the soft lights, the gentle breeze, and a nice ceiling fan provided a wonderful ambience that helped us begin our "decompression" and relaxation process.Our bodies were on Colorado time, so we naturally woke up at 6 a.m., and everything was still very peaceful, except that the most wonderful bird songs were now being performed for us--it was quite enchanting. I'm an opera singer, and one of the birds sang a song that reminded me of the Queen of the Night aria from Mozart's "Magic Flute." (That's my story and I'm sticking to it.)My wife, a professional hairstylist, had forgotten her shampoo, and she commented that she was impressed with the quality of the hair products in the room--in case anyone is wondering.We went down for breakfast promptly at 7:30 and were very happy to find delicious fruit (pineapple, apple and some fantastic papaya) along with delicious coffee, orange juice, hard-boiled eggs and breads for toasting. The beautiful veranda had lovely views of the lush and well-kept grounds. My wife, who doesn't share my "lumberjack" breakfast tastes, was happy with all of it ("perfect"), and so was I.Unfortunately, we didn't get an opportunity to try out the heated salt-water pool in the garden (available to discreet guests anytime day or night), but we really enjoyed a short walk around the yard and the gardens. There are some lovely places to relax and smoke outside in designated areas. Unfortunately, I hadn't hit the cigar shop yet, but I regretted not having the opportunity to have a nice, quiet smoke out in the lush backyard.Theresa helped us with directions to local shopping in the neighborhood, and also kindly passed along her insider tips for eating and beach-activities on the island.We're looking forward to going back, and we recommend this property whole-heartedly to anyone who is looking for a simple, lovely and comfortable stay at a reasonable price.

Manoa Valley Inn needs a fresh, energetic proprietor to relieve the owner of the task of running a business that her heart is not in. The Inn has such potential - financial and community-serving that is sadly being ignored. The current owner has had the Inn on and off the market for years - making it clear to guests that the interest in successfully running a for-profit Inn isn't what she wants to be doing. Therefore, I am writing this review critically and candidly, since the owner is an acquaintance of mine. Purchasing an historical landmark in Hawaii is a huge decision - I am seeking an investor who would like to work with me to revive the Inn and provide visitors the most wonderful Bed & Breakfast experience they'll ever have. After staying at the Inn myself as Housekeeper for 6 months, I have keen insight into what needs to be done. I have a detailed business plan and am looking forward to hearing from an investor/ business partner who would like to take on this project. Many people have had a wonderful time at the Inn over the years - but now is the time for a fresh revival !

My husband and I have stayed at a number of bed and breakfasts and and have had wonderful experiences but this was not one I can add to this list.The Moana Valley Inn was dissapointing. The hosts were helpful but we felt they were weary of the whole B&B thing and were just biding time until they sell (The inn is on the market).The house & decor would have been beautiful in its time but now looked tired, faded and unloved. Breakfast was reasonable if you were one of the first to eat, if you were late you got left overs. Nothing was restocked in our experience. The location for breakfast on the back veranda had a wonderful view of Honolulu and it also over looked the garden which could have done with some loving attention.There was no community sitting room which meant you were confined to your bedroom or the vernadah. We were not made aware of any tea/coffee making facilities outside of breadfast time.

My husband and I spent two nights at the inn and loved it. Our room, a suite, was beautifully furnished with various antiques and very roomy. The gardens wrapping around the home were beautiful...lots of birds enjoying them as well. Many nooks for privacy in the garden and a small pool to enjoy. We just did not have enough time to take advantage of it all. The proprietors offered us a wealth of information on where to eat, park, play, etc based on our requests and needs. They were amazing and so relaxed. Enjoyed the fresh tropical fruits for breakfast, coffee, etc on the lovely veranda....very comfortable, easy-going, lovely place to stay. Beautiful people and a beautiful experience...enjoy your time there!

We had a great time, a very pleasant stay. They home is very quaint, an early-Century Victorian. The owners, Theresa and John, were really friendly and knowledgable about places to go and things to do; lot of great stories about life and times in Hawaii.

My husband and I totally enjoyed our 3 day stay at the Manoa Valley Inn in March. The house itself is a treasure. An old historic home with lots of interesting features tastefully decorated. Our spacious and comfortable room was on the top floor among the trees and the birds and we had a fantastic view of Waikiki out our window. Though the room is not air-conditioned it was quite comfortable and it was nice to hear the birds. Theresa and John were friendly and helpful. Their suggestions for dinner were spot on. We ate at a fabulous Italian place and another night a very good thai called Sweet Basil. The breakfasts out on the veranda were very nice and plentiful including cereals breads and fresh fruits. We found the location to be a nice change from the beaches that we had thoroughly enjoyed also and we would recommend this place to anyone.

manoa valley inn is a wonderful retreat spot close to everything hawaii has to offer. the rooms are spacious, clean and homey. the grounds are well kept, beautiful flora and fauna everywhere and the hospitality of the hosts was great! I would definately stay there again with my boyfriend and would recommend it to anyone I know.Have a nice day and keep smiling!Lucky Michelle

The property is a Victorian home in a suburban area near the University. The room we had was spacious and looked out over the garden. The room was not air conditioned but we had a nice breeze each night and it was very pleasant.Breakfast was served on a large veranda, with the garden below, the Waikiki area spreading out beneath the garden, and a beautiful view of Diamond Head. A great way to start the day.Both John and Theresa are very hospitable. They were very helpful,with things to see, how to get there and where to park.In fact, after we left for another island we realized i"d left some shirts in the room. I called Theresa, and she packaged them up and took them to Federal Express, so I could use them on the rest of our trip.The Asian resturant, just a few blocks away, was a real treat.All in all we had a great time and would definitely stay there again.

Three companions and I had a very disapponting, disturbing, and expensive experience, which was the low point of our one week cruise of the Islands and one week stay at Manoa Valley Inn (2001 Vancouver Drive, Honolulu, Hawaii 96822) split up between April 4 and April 18.Their glossy pamphlet lists them on the National Registry of Historic Places, and they claim a 5-star rating with Fisher's Guide to Hawaii.We seek out bed & breakfasts to have a better experience than one can have at a hotel. Based on the pictures, pamphlet info, and web and travel book info, one would get the impression that at Manola Valley Inn, one would be treated with efficient, generous hospitality. This was not the case:Some of the problems:-Reservations initially lost and had to be remade-Our names incorrect when we arrived-Manager thought we were leaving when when we were arriving -3rd floor room so hot and stuffy we had to move to the "carriage house," a converted garage with ripped screening completing the upper walls, cockroaches, and rusting paint cans around doorway-No kindly assistance with luggage to 3rd floor -Filthy windows obscure view-Some lights had to be jiggled to work-If you make reservations over the phone instead of at their web site, you will not be told of the lack of AC and TVs, just the size of the bed and the availability of a private bath. This is a problem especially for folks with asthma or a heart condition, or insomnia-Until we complained, their "exemplary" continental breakfast Moon Travel Guide) was questionable supermarket packaged sliced bread and one kind of bagel, lukewarm coffee, and no half and half. You got mangoes and papayas only if there were any ripe on their trees.-Trash cans lined with used supermarket plastic bags-Staff eats their "full, hot" breakfasts in front of guests-No welcoming afternoon tea or evening wine and cheese that 5-star bed and breakfasts offer their guests.-Dodged heavy shingles that flew off their roof, left by the roofers over the weekend.-Newspaper seldom available-Owner vocally claims puzzle page for herself and her staff -Reminded that we could reuse our towels-Reminded that we don't have to have our rooms serviced daily-lack of back porch lights is dangerous & discourages nightly gatherings-Catching a movie more important than dealing with guests comfort issue-Ownersdogs wake you every morning at 7 a.m.-Called property manager twice at adjoining, low-income housing about a child sceaming and begging his mother not to hurt him (police apparently won't come out unless you know exactly where the screams are coming from)Beautiful garden and morning vistas of Honolulu and Diamond Head from the back porch, just didn't justify the pricey room charges for this property, when one adds up the lack of amenities and aggravation.This review is the subjective opinion of a TripAdvisor member and not of TripAdvisor LLC

We decided to stay in this place because first I’m a B&B lover, (we always stay at B&B’s if possible) and because of the glorious reviews from some major tour books. And I just couldn’t believe what I read and what I experienced is the same thing. Let me summarize the differences:o. Room – as some previous reviewers pointed out, it’s dusty, musty and fading. You have to keep the fan going all the time to expel the musty smell. Half the windows don’t open, the ones that open are propped up with a stick. It also has the most interesting (or least user-friendly) lavatory and faucet in my life. The spout of the faucet sits against the side of the sink, thus there is no room for your hands underneath. The only way to wash your hands is fill the sink with water, which is time-consuming and wastes water. Oh, and did I mention the big cockroach in the room?o. Breakfast – It's meager. One word to describe the bread is “stale”. Orange juice must be very expensive in Oahu as there is never enough. One morning we were the first to arrive at the breakfast table and the orange juice jar was only half-filled, it didn’t even fill 4 small glasses and it wasn’t refilled even when we left. Yogurt made rare appearances in some days and totally disappeared in others.o. Public Area – other than a porch in the back there is NONE. The owners took up the first floor, thus there is no parlor, no living room, no reading room as mentioned in some tour books.o. Swimming Pool – owners only. The best part of the backyard is closed off with a gate and a sign on the door “Owners only”. Looking in from the gate it’s a lovely area complete with a palapa thatched pavilion and a pretty pool with stone waterfall that you could only drool about.o. AC – again first floor only, that means the owner’s residence only.o. Room Safe – I finally found one in the far end of our closet with its door completely blocked by an old mattress.o. Phone – None. They don’t even have a basic phone, where is the dataport mentioned in the book?o. Parking – not guaranteed. Some nights we couldn’t find parking and had to park across the street.I truly believe there must have been a change of ownership some time ago since it’s very different from the place described by the tour books. It probably used to be a nice, classy place but with the current owners it’s run like a Motel 6. No, Motel 6 is cleaner and more hospitable!

I’m still not sure I’m totally recovered from the “Manoa Valley Inn” nightmare.We were taking my 85-yea- old parents for their first trip to Hawaii. Since my mom is in a wheelchair my top criterion is wheel chair accessibility. The owner assured me that they have a “lovely cottage” in the garden that’s ground level and wheel chair accessible (not the Alexander cottage, which wasn’t available), “No, there is no picture on the web, it’s newly added and it’s lovely.”, I was assured. Turns out this “lovely cottage” is a converted garage! No, converted garage is an euphemism, it’s the original garage structure with a bunch of cheap furnitures thrown in, or it’s more like a carport since the walls don’t go all the way to the ceiling. The area between the walls and the ceiling is enclosed with tattered screens, with bigger holes filled in with tissues (to keep off bugs?) This “cottage” is reachable by a narrow and winding path made of gravels and paving stones, it would probably fit the wheel chair if I cut the chair in half length-wise. On top of that it’s totally unlit. Since we arrived after dark and it was raining, even I (an avid hiker) had problem negotiating it, not to say my 85 year old mom in a wheel chair. How we stumbled to the room was a mystery. After a careful study I found there were actually flood lights outside the door (as it’s a garage) but it took us even longer to find the switch because it’s taped shut! An un-lit, uneven path is a hazard to anyone, and this is what they called “wheelchair accessible” room??? If their goal is to achieve a “garage theme” I’d say they are very successful. The light fixture in the center of the room is a fluorescent shop light, true to its past. The closet is the plastic kind that hangs from the ceiling. The bedding is the cheapest, ugliest I have ever seen compared with the B&B’s I have stayed (which is a lot, as you can see I would choose a B&B instead of a Waikiki high-rise). There are no windows, but thanks to the screened-in gap between the walls and the ceiling there is plenty of ventilation, maybe too much since every night the wind was howling and it blew from one end to the other and was excruciatingly noisy. On top of that you still hear street noise, this place is in no way “quiet” as described by some tour books. There was no hot water the first night, when I reported the problem to the owner I got blank stares. I had to suggest “Can you take a look” before I got a response. And what irks me the most is we paid top dollars for this! It’s charged the same as a room in the main building with a private bath!

Where do I start? I wanted to be out of the fast pace of Honolulu, so found this b and b - the website made it look as if the place was in a secluded valley, but it is in suburbia - 1st issue. We arrived to have the owner almost demand our visa as we walked in the door and got a 'you are on the third floor - you have lots of bags, but you're young!'. No help with those, but I still have an open mind. Room was fine - no tv which isn't a big deal, half used shampoos (ok, I'm not fussy, but that's just stingy!). Breakfast the next morning we were down there at 730 as directed. The breakfast consists of a few muffins, coffee that runs out in 5 minutes, had to ask for milk, a bit of fruit. Really, very average for somewhere calling themselves a b and b. We ended up eating at a nearby cafe since we found the whole breakfast thing quite stressful rather than relaxing as a b and b should be. The owners are interesting people - pretend to be super friendly, but are very rude, in what they see is normal behaviour. My fiancee and I have stayed at hundreds of places throughout Europe, the states and Oz, and this b and b was awful. It is very overpriced and while a jaguar sits out front, the owners are stingy in their hospitality. When guests are coming down to breakfast to be told by Theresa, the owner 'oh I forgot about you' in her provisioning, you know there are problems. Stay in Honolulu or up on the north coast if you have a car - very chilled out and normal unlike the Manoa Valley Inn.

I lived on Oahu for a decade, and have been lucky enough to return often. Far and away, my favorite place to stay is the Manoa Valley Inn. The ambience and staff encompass the best of that which makes Hawaii special. It's quaint, peaceful, and friendly. Now, having said that, one thing I've observed about most tourists, is that even though they complain about the 'real Hawaii' being hard to find, they often have a hard time experiencing anything outside their comfort zone of sterile, air-conditioned, impersonal, high-rise towers. The Manoa Valley Inn is there for those who really want to visit Hawaii.

We experienced the earthquake (Oct 15, 2006) and some damage to the home - but the owners managed to provide breakfast and hot coffee only moments later. Without power for 17 hours (throughout the island) and water for several, they still kept us content and happy with their hospitality. Home is beautiful older home in universit neighborhood (quiet while we were there) - quaint - one of very few left on Oahu with some character. Rooms are comfortable and the antiques are amazing.We would return and recommend this for those who enjoy amazing views - of the city and Diamond Head.Donna/Dave

[-]We stayed there in February '06 and really liked the place for its ambience and location. However, the owners have yet to respond to my several email requests for an explanation of the charges to our credit card. Admittedly, our stay was complicated as it involved room changes and was interrupted by a several-day trip to Kauai, but...not a word., even if to claim that they were right and I was wrong.So, if you go, get all the rates nailed down and agreed-to before you give your credit card number.

The Manoa Valley Inn provided just the refreshing type of experience that we were looking for, the opposite end of the spectrum from the predictable western hotel experiences that can easily be found in mass quantity along Waikiki beach. Located only a short distance from the bustle of Waikiki, the surroundings were a welcomed calm from our busy day excursions. Located centrally, the Manoa Valley Inn is conveniently close to a number of great beaches, Diamond Head and Manoa Falls. A rental car is needed. John and Theresa were welcoming hosts, who willingly shared their vast local knowledge of outstanding places to dine from local ‘hole in the walls’ to high end restaurants, sites of interest for day excursions and fantastic beaches to bathe on. We stayed in the artistically decorated Sunroom located on the second floor, which had a comfortable double bed and an antique Asian opium bed. The surrounding windows offered a majestic view of Waikiki and allowed the song of morning birds to filter in. The included breakfast was light, offering English muffins and toast, fruit, coffee, tea and juice. If you’re looking for a non commercial experience of Oahu, then Manoa Valley Inn is worth considering.

This was our first time going to a bed and breakfast. Walking out on the varanda in the morning was such a pleasant way to start the day. Birds in the yard, smell of beautiful flowers and a fresh arrangement of fruit was wonderful. The view in the evening was just fabulous. After one drive to Honolulu at night, we decided to stay close to home in the evening. A bottle of wine, wonderful guest to enjoy and a view that was beyond compare - this was Hawaii! We are from a small town in Washington and we felt very safe staying at the Manoa Valley Inn.

Not enough room to complain fully.Section 8/student housing next door which means screaming kids and drunks. Cranky owners, terrible parking, no services except toast and fruit which are gone by 9am. our expensive cheese was frozen solid in the in room mini refer, the owners' dogs run around and you get flea bites on the back porch ("veranda" they call it). Pushy and rude owners as well. We were here for a wedding, can't believe we wasted our money on this waste of valuable real estate. Mildew in the bathrooms, the owners kept turning off the fan in our room (I guess to save money) which meant the place was muggy all the time. The place was having work done and the workers (and the owners) regularly blocked in guest's cars in the lot.

after spending four nights ($120 and $160 per night) for two different rooms, I feel comfortable writing this review. Upside - in a quiet neighborhood with gorgeous landscaping in the backyard, 1.9 miles from Waikiki. The house was built in 1912 with a massive amount of wood from the N.W. I had no issue with the decorations or bedding, but the bathrooms were not re-stocked daily with simple things like soap, tp and shampoo. We had both a private bath and a shared bath (needs a new shower) on this visit. While the veranda was very nice, everything there was rather dirty. The in-room literature said we could use beach towels, but the owner was very put out about getting us the towels when I (very politely) asked after I had mentioned we were going to the beach one hour earlier. After the second day, I found it easier to talk with her husband (if you can find him) and avoided her at all cost after having more run-ins with her. Not the best host. The 'breakfast' would be considered continental by most standards, not a b & b breakfast. I would recommend different managers to bring the place up to snuff, then it would be fabulous.

Unbelievable that they dare offer rooms here. The place charges top dollar for rooms that are musty, dusty and fading. for our room we had to cross the living area, the hallway, the owner's dining room and the pantry to get to our "private bath" which though clean was poorly ventilated. The door connecting to the living room from our unit could not be locked. A fact which Theresa dismissed: "With oh yes, those old doors." The other door which led outside was difficult to lock because the handle kept falling off. "Breakfast" as noted by another reviewer was so far from the expected standards of B and B's as to be unworthy of the name. The windows were covered with sheet like fabric that did little too diminish the intensity of the searchlights shining through our windows. It was like trying to sleep on the beach. (Which would in every respect have been more pleasant.)There must be something good to say. Oh yes, the verandah is lovely, but since they had workmen pounding on cabinets there , it's loveliness was diminished to say the least.The owners need an education in what even a minimal B & B is.

My husband and I have stayed at many bed and breakfasts and inns over the years and have had wonderful experiences. Until now. The Moana Valley Inn was a major disappointment. The staff was nice enough but the inn lacked the usual thoughtfulness and care that typically accompanies inns and B&Bs. From the faded comforter on our bed, to the peeling paint, to the can of "Raid" ant killer in our bathroom (in plain sight!), to the day old newspaper at breakfast, to the raggedy landscaping, it was evident that no one cared. And we stayed in the most expensive room in the inn - the Alexander Cottage - described as an ideal spot for honeymooners. It did not inspire romance at all.Breakfast, typically a place for B&B's to shine, was dismal. All we got to eat was a fruit plate and piles of white bread with a toaster. That was it. Drinks included some sort of fruit punch, coffee, and tea. The location for breakfast was the back veranda, which had a wonderful view of Honolulu. That and the friendly cat "Yoda" were the two highlights of the inn. Everything else was disappointing. Note: They have two dogs in addition to the cat.

Larry and I stayed at the Manoa Valley Inn from Dec. 29, 2004 to Jan. 2, 2005. We enjoyed our stay there. The rooms are large and beautifully decorated. The showers are great, very large. We enjoyed the quiet neighborhood that enabled us to hear the birdsong in the mornings. The gardens and yards are beautifully displayed and cared for. Our breakfasts on the lanai were delicious, ample, and relaxing while we enjoyed the view of Diamondhead. John and Teresa were very helpful in making our stay a happy and enjoyable time. They provided us with directions to a specific shopping excursion and provided information on good restaurants for lunch.

We always like the B&Bs on the mainland so decided to give this one a try. Everything was so dusty and dirty, I didn't feel comfortable sitting on any of the furniture! There was a condom wrapper poking out of the bedskirt and other people's clothes in the drawers. I'd say this B&B was in its prime about 30 years ago. When we went, the inn was owned by a husband and wife who were both very bizarre (paranoid schizophrenics perhaps?). The only good thing about the place was the husband told us about a great beach. As it happened, I left my bathingsuit in the shower and called from the big island to see if they could ship it over. After several calls, and giving them our Fed EX number, they finally sent it. It took five days (!!) and it was sopping wet and very ruined. If you like trash, this place is for you.
